III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person
Section contact
Description • (3) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
parents and children except where parental rights have
been terminated or when there is a court determination that
visits are detrimental to the child.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is withholding visits between youth and parents.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on June 17, 2025.
She stated she is concerned about a family that had their 4
children removed from their care in October 2024. Initially the
children were placed with Relative Caregiver. While in the care of
Relative Caregiver there were no concerns regarding visitation
with parents.
On March 18, 2025, the children were moved from Relative
Caregiver into licensed foster homes. Youth A is placed in one
foster home, Youth B and C in separate foster home and Youth D
in another foster home. Complainant stated visitation is occurring
between the parents and Youth B, Youth C and Youth D but ever
since the placement change occurred the visits with Youth A and
her parents have been sporadic. Complainant stated Foster Care
worker (FCW) reported the reason for inconsistent visitation with
Youth A is due to a court order that states Youth A has discretion
to participate in visitation and Youth A has chosen not to
participate in the visits.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via video
conference on June 23, 2025. She stated she has been the
assigned worker since January 2025. At the time she became
involved the children were all placed with Relative Caregiver.
Parenting time between the children and parents were supervised
by Relative Caregiver in her home at the time she was assigned to
the case.
On March 18, 2025, the children were moved to separate licensed
foster homes. The agency set up days and times for visits to occur
between parents and children at the DHS office, however the
parents initially refused to communicate with the agency until after
a court hearing that occurred on March 26, 2025. FCW stated
visitation is scheduled weekly and has been consistently occurring
between parents and Youth B, Youth C & Youth D. However, due
to allegations Youth A was sexually abused by Parent 1 the
December 2, 2024 court order stated she had the discretion
whether or not to participate in visit with her parents. Youth A has
participated in 2 visits with her parents but has chosen to not
participate in the other visits scheduled. FCW stated she regularly
inquires if Youth A would like to participate and documents her
response in the MISACWIS case file.
2

Foster Care supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed via
telephone on June 23, 2025. She stated all parenting visits have
been occurring with Youth B, Youth C & Youth D. One of the main
reasons the youth are in foster care is due to allegations Youth A
was sexually abused by Parent 1. Due to the concerns the court
ordered visits between Youth A and her parents will occur at
Youth A’s discretion. Up to this point Youth A has chosen not to
participate in the majority of scheduled visits but is regularly asked
if she would like to participate.
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on July 18, 2025. She
stated she has been having regular visits with her siblings. As far
as visits with her parents, Youth A stated based on a court order it
is her choice if she chooses to visit with her parents. Youth A
stated FCW consistently inquires if she would like to visit with her
parents and she has been declining the visits.
Documents reviewed:
• December 2, 2024, court order. Visitation between Youth A
and Parent 1 & Parent 2 is at the discretion of Youth A.
• December 9, 2024, Parenting Time Exception. Exception
regarding visits between Parent 1 & Parent 2. Reason: It
has been court ordered that Youth A has the discretion to
choose whether to participate in parenting time visits or not.
• MISACWIS case file for Youth A. Social work contacts
reviewed document FCW inquires monthly if Youth A would
like to participate in visitation with Parent 1 & Parent 2 and
she declines the visitations.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of the MISACWIS case file the children
were removed from the care of Parent 1 and Parent 2 in part, due
to allegations Youth A was sexually abused by Parent 1. Due to
the nature of the allegations the December 2, 2024 court order
states Youth A has discretion on whether to participate in visitation
with her parents and she has chosen not to participate in the
majority of scheduled visitation.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person
Section contact
Description • (4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
siblings who are not placed together except when there is a
court determination that contact is detrimental to either
child.
3

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is withholding sibling visits.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on June 17, 2025.
She stated she is concerned about a family that had their 4
children removed from their care in October 2024. Initially the
children were placed with Relative Caregiver. While in the care of
Relative Caregiver there were no concerns regarding sibling visits
since they were together.
On March 18, 2025, the children were moved from Relative
Caregiver into licensed foster homes. Youth A is placed in one
foster home, Youth B and Youth C in a separate foster home and
Youth D in another foster home. Complainant stated visitation
between the siblings has been consistently occurring.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via video
conference on June 23, 2025. She stated she has been the
assigned worker since January 2025. At the time she became
involved the children were all placed with Relative Caregiver.
On March 18, 2025, the children were moved to separate licensed
foster homes. FCW stated she has been diligent about ensuring
sibling visits and those have been occurring regularly. There is
always one big visit between siblings at the agency each month
and the foster parents of the children also work together to ensure
additional sibling visits occur.
Foster Care supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed via
telephone on June 23, 2025. She stated all sibling visits have
been occurring with Youth A, Youth B, Youth C & Youth D and are
documented in the MISACWIS case file.
Documents reviewed:
• MISACWIS case file for Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, &
Youth D. Placement records show children were placed
together with Relative Caregiver until March 18, 2025.
Sibling visits are documented as occurring every month
since placement change occurred in March 2025.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance based on completed interviews
and review of the MISACWIS case file sibling visits are occurring
at least once per month.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
